repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
For now let's get optimisation of int variable on par with untype variable. Further optimisations can be done in separate PR.

Fixes #5783.

comment_data.body: Just curious about why you removed `__div__` in the second commit? (Not suggesting you should spend time making it work if it doesn't though... just asking what doesn't work)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3463,6 +3463,20 @@ def _handle_simple_method_object___truediv__(self, node, function, args, is_unbo
     def _handle_simple_method_object___div__(self, node, function, args, is_unbound_method):
         return self._optimise_num_div('Divide', node, function, args, is_unbound_method)
 
+    _handle_simple_method_int___add__ = _handle_simple_method_object___add__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___sub__ = _handle_simple_method_object___sub__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___mul__ = _handle_simple_method_object___mul__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___eq__ = _handle_simple_method_object___eq__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___ne__ = _handle_simple_method_object___ne__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___and__ = _handle_simple_method_object___and__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___or__ = _handle_simple_method_object___or__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___xor__ = _handle_simple_method_object___xor__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___rshift__ = _handle_simple_method_object___rshift__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___lshift__ = _handle_simple_method_object___lshift__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___mod__ = _handle_simple_method_object___mod__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___floordiv__ = _handle_simple_method_object___floordiv__
+    _handle_simple_method_int___truediv__ = _handle_simple_method_object___truediv__
+

comment_data.body:
Probably worth adding `test_fail_if_path_exists`/`test_assert_path_exists`. I'd guess it should fail with `BinopNode`, and we should require a `CApiCallNode`. But I'm not completely sure of this off the top of my head.

For debugging purposes it's useful to temporarily add `PrintTree()` to the end of the pipeline in `Pipeline.py` - I think there might be a command line argument to do it but I find it easier just to edit the code
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +515,130 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+def pure_add_int(obj2: int):

comment_data.body:
I added it first but then removed because:
1. it does no optimisation, if I am not wrong
2. it is only for python2 so I decided to simplify the PR

I was thinking about that. I did not added them because the PR is not changing tree but I will try to add them.

comment_data.body:
I believe the PR will change the tree - it replaces a `BinopNode` with a function call of the optimized function.

> I  suppose this is just a note, It should not be added in this PR...

Yes - it was just a hint about how to work out what the tree is changed to.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +515,130 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+def pure_add_int(obj2: int):

comment_data.body: It might just be easier to drop this test rather than spending too much time working out how to make it work in Python 2. (I think __all__ docstrings might be put into a tests dictionary on Python 2 at compile time so this might be hard to make work right)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +515,145 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+def pure_add_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_add_int(1)
+    (2, 2)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 + 1
+    res2 = 1 + obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_sub_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_sub_int(1)
+    (0, 0)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 - 1
+    res2 = 1 - obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_mul_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_mul_int(2)
+    (4, 4)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 * 2
+    res2 = 2 * obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_eq_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_eq_int(2)
+    (True, True)
+    >>> pure_eq_int(3)
+    (False, False)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 == 2
+    res2 = 2 == obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_ne_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_ne_int(2)
+    (False, False)
+    >>> pure_ne_int(3)
+    (True, True)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 != 2
+    res2 = 2 != obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_and_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_and_int(1)
+    (0, 0)
+    >>> pure_and_int(3)
+    (2, 2)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 & 2
+    res2 = 2 & obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_or_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_or_int(1)
+    (3, 3)
+    >>> pure_or_int(0)
+    (2, 2)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 | 2
+    res2 = 2 | obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_xor_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_xor_int(1)
+    (3, 3)
+    >>> pure_xor_int(3)
+    (1, 1)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 ^ 2
+    res2 = 2 ^ obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_rshift_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_rshift_int(8)
+    (4, 0)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 >> 1
+    res2 = 8 >> obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_lshift_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_lshift_int(8)
+    (16, 2048)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 << 1
+    res2 = 8 << obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_mod_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_mod_int(3)
+    (1, 2)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 % 2
+    res2 = 5 % obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+def pure_floordiv_int(obj2: int):
+    """
+    >>> pure_floordiv_int(3)
+    (1, 2)
+    """
+    res1 = obj2 // 2
+    res2 = 7 // obj2
+    return res1, res2
+
+import sys
+
+if sys.version_info < (3, 0):

comment_data.body: I think I fixed it. In dirty way but hopefully it will be deleted soon when we will clean cython from all python 2.7 old crust.

comment_data.body: This will allow to have code exercised in python3.

comment_data.body:
> I believe the PR will change the tree

Hmm OK I was not aware of that. I am still stranger in Cython internals...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +515,130 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+def pure_add_int(obj2: int):

comment_data.body:
OK done. It was good hint because I found out that PR was not exercised because annotations were ignored. Hence, there are two major changes:
1. language_level was set to 3, I hope it does not affect rest of the tests
2. I have removed reversed tests for non-Commutativity operations because it generates different code when operands are reversed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +515,130 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+def pure_add_int(obj2: int):

comment_data.body:
Not sure if we need the Python `long` type here as well. That might not settle itself before Cython 3.1…
Annotations will probably use `int`, so let's stick to that.
```suggestion
        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type and arg0.type is not Builtin.int_type:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4207,12 +4221,12 @@ def optimise_numeric_binop(operator, node, ret_type, arg0, arg1):
     # Prefer constants on RHS as they allows better size control for some operators.
     num_nodes = (ExprNodes.IntNode, ExprNodes.FloatNode)
     if isinstance(arg1, num_nodes):
-        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type and arg0.type is not Builtin.builtin_types['int']:

@@ -4207,12 +4221,12 @@ def optimise_numeric_binop(operator, node, ret_type, arg0, arg1):
     # Prefer constants on RHS as they allows better size control for some operators.
     num_nodes = (ExprNodes.IntNode, ExprNodes.FloatNode)
     if isinstance(arg1, num_nodes):
-        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type and arg0.type is not Builtin.builtin_types['int']:
             return None
         numval = arg1
         arg_order = 'ObjC'
     elif isinstance(arg0, num_nodes):
-        if arg1.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+        if arg1.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type and arg1.type is not Builtin.builtin_types['int']:

comment_data.body:
Let's just use the new default. No need to nail the string  type as well.
```suggestion
# cython: language_level=3str
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
+# cython: language_level=3

comment_data.body: I'd really check for a generic `BinopNode` for the tests, not a specific one. Especially not something as half-specific as `IntBinopNode`. Whether that's used or not depends on other factors than just this PR. We're not expecting any `BinopNode` at all in the test functions and don't want the tests to become no-ops by accident when we add other optimisations.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +516,158 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists('//AddNode')

comment_data.body:
> I'd really check for a generic `BinopNode` for the tests, not a specific one. 

When trying to substitude `'//AddNode'` with `'//BinopNode'` the test is not failing when the fix is not present. I suppose tests added should fail when the fix is not present (e.g. on master branch). Moreover, when I print the tree of the test there is no `BinopNode` present:
```
          - stats[0]: DefNode(name="pure_add_int")
            - args[0]: CArgDeclNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:522:17))
              - base_type: CAnalysedBaseTypeNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:522:23))
              - declarator: CNameDeclaratorNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:522:17))
              - annotation: AnnotationNode(type=None)
            - body: StatListNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:523:4))
              - stats[0]: CompilerDirectivesNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:523:4))
                - body: StatListNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:523:4))
                  - stats[0]: SingleAssignmentNode(pos=(pyintop.pyx:527:16))
                    - lhs: NameNode(type=<PyObjectType>, name="res1")
                    - rhs: AddNode(type=<PyObjectType>)
                      - operand1: NameNode(type=<PyInt_Type>, name="obj2")
                      - operand2: IntNode(type=<PyObjectType>, value='1')
```
That's why I used specific nodes instead of generic `BinopNode`. Am I missing something?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,3 +516,158 @@ def test_avoid_if_coercion(obj):
         return True
     else:
         return False
+
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists('//AddNode')

comment_data.body:
Don't think so. At least according to the wiki (https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/HackerGuide#parse-tree-assertions)

> You can express assertions using a simple XPath-like language called TreePath that traverses the parse tree. Nodes are referred to by their type name (inheritance is not considered).

It's possible we might want to improve that but I don't think as part of this PR.

-----------------------

One thing you could do is add separate "fail" tests for the base classes. E.g. this one would be 

```
@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists('//AddNode')
@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists('//NumBinopNode')
@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists('//BinopNode')
```

That gives a higher chance of catching it if some optimization changes
comment_data.diff_hunk:
